contextId.information: Here "royal throne" may refer to his rule over the kingdom. AT: "ruled the empire" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Speech coming out of the mouth is a metonym that represents speaking. AT: "As soon as the king said this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: As soon as this sentence came out of the king's mouth

contextId.information: Writing something in the king's name represents writing it with his authority, or writing it as his representative. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Write ... in the name of the king

contextId.information: The "city" represents the people living in it. AT: "the people of the city of Susa shouted and rejoiced" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the city of Susa shouted and rejoiced

contextId.information: Laying hands on people is a metonym for fighting against them. AT: "to fight their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to lay hands on those who tried to bring disaster on them

contextId.information: To impose a tax means to make people pay a tax. The land and coastlands represent the people living there. AT: "made the people living in the land and on the coastlands along the sea pay a tax" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: imposed a tax on the land and on the coastlands along the sea
